and the handshake should no longer successfully complete another example of
a test generation rule is that you repeat or replay certain messages and
the and shake on that does not negatively affect the handshake because in a Wi-Fi
network it's common that some messages are lost and that they are retransmitted meaning this specific modification would
still result in a handshake that should be successful and should result in a successful connection so these test
generation rules they basically apply correct and incorrect modification to
this normal handshake and the idea is that by defining various types of test

handshake but doesn't apply to the TLS or ssh handshake one small limitation of our technique is
that we assume that these test generation rules are independent in other words we do not apply two or three
test generation rules at the same time because that would mean we have to try all possible combinations which would
result in an exponential state space explosion and we don't have enough time
in real life to test all that ok so we have our normal handshake we apply these
test generation rules on then we get a set of test cases now what do I mean with a test case here well a test case
basically defines the messages that we want to send to an implementation under test on the replies we expect and return
and if we don't get this expected reply and something is wrong the second part
of the test case defines is whether this results an exact successful connection or not because sometimes you may always

on their tests okay so we have our test cases how are we going to execute these
test cases well it's fairly straightforward we take a test case we
run it if you get an unexpected reply we're going to save this test case and then we're going to reset the

the implementation under test for an TLS library this would mean closing the
TCP connection for example let's say we always got to expect the replies then we're going to see if the connection is

back that means that the implementation under test considered the handshake to

implementation under test on execute the next test case so as you can imagine
we're now going to focus after it's purely on the failed test cases and then
the idea is that an expert examines why these test cases have failed this can be
